quickOverviewContent1.title: Installation
quickOverviewContent1.text1: Software articles should describe a tool likely to be of broad utility that represents a significant advance over previously published software (usually demonstrated by direct comparison with available related software).
quickOverviewContent1.text2: The software application/tool described in the manuscript must be available for testing by reviewers in a way that preserves their anonymity. If published, software applications/tools must be freely available to any researcher wishing to use them for non-commercial purposes, without restrictions such as the need for a material transfer agreement. Because web-links frequently become broken, BMC strongly recommends that all software applications/tools are included with the submitted manuscript as additional files to ensure that the software will continue to be available.
quickOverviewContent1.text3: BMC recommends, but does not require, that the source code of the software should be made available under a suitable open-source license that will entitle other researchers to further develop and extend the software if they wish to do so. Typically, an archive of the source code of the current version of the software should be included with the submitted manuscript as a supplementary file.

screenshot7.text2: There is a global positive impact of mobile application. Using mobile application developed country are becoming facilitate and people, society of developing country are upgrading themselves and making a new type of IT infrastructure.
screenshot7.text3: In large number of mobile application some are pre-installed in phone and others user can download from internet and install it in mobile phone.

blogDetail.title: Talisker Bay on the Isle of Skye in Scotland
blogDetail.subtitle: Typography should be use:
blogDetail.text1: A quick blog post from April 2020 started things off early, making the prediction that after our pandemic finally ends, we’d have a second Roaring ’20s. “100 years ago: An election, a virus and a cry from disillusioned youths,” ran a headline in the Washington Post in October for a story drawing suggestive comparisons between the two decades that are separated by a hundred years of history. As we limped into 2021, the comparisons picked up. “The 1920s Roared After a Pandemic, and the 2020s Will Try,” ran a Fun thoughts aside, however,
blogDetail.text2: Fun thoughts aside, however, my “hmm” reflex at historical comparisons is strong, and it’s been further honed by the “Is this fascism?” wars of 2016–21. At least one historian of the 1920s whom I reached out to for an interview for this piece said that the prediction of a “new ’20s” was so strained as to be not worth exploring. Steve LeVine, focusing on points of economic comparison in that piece in Marker, also thought: Probably not. LeVine points out a few key
blogDetail.text3: The “new ’20s” idea might not work—there were a lot more young people in the United States then than now; a reprise of the world-changing inventions and discoveries of the 1920s would be a big surprise to those economists who believe that we have been in an invention dry spell since the 1970s. In his Businessweek piece, Peter Coy largely agrees, writing, “In all probability
blogDetail.text4: Anyway, let’s get to that fun. A very joyful book to read about the decade is Frederick Lewis Allen’s Only Yesterday: An Informal History of the 1920s, which Allen—a blueblood journalist and editor at Harper’s—published in 1931. The book chronicles all of the movement and motion that makes the decade sexy, and doesn’t seem to miss a fad. Among the fleeting obsessions Allen catalogs are “the sudden and overwhelming craze for Eskimo Pie” that made the price of
blogDetail.text5: I describe the “fun” parts of Only Yesterday because they’re wonderful, but also to make a point about the origin story we’ve learned about the mood of the ’20s. Looking back at Allen’s work from the vantage point of 1986, historian David M. Kennedy argued that the biggest failing of the book was its lack of historical depth: “Rarely did Allen forge an explanatory chain whose links ran back more deeply into the past than 1917.” And indeed, Allen seemed to blame World War I for every ash-covered carpet and scarred dining table. Young people who had been overseas and seen so much blood were not ready to conform, Allen wrote:
blogDetail.text6: Allen is also really good at describing parties—or, at least, the ones the middle class and upper class attended. The historian wrote about how women taking up smoking had “strewed the dinner table with their ashes, snatched a puff between the acts, invaded the masculine sanctity of the club car, and forced department stores to place ornamental ash-trays between the chairs in their women’s shoe departments.” In what I think may be the best passage in the book, Allen described the way 1920s partygoers stepped all over every previous genteel convention:
blogDetail.text7: Anyway, let’s get to that fun. A very joyful book to read about the decade is Frederick Lewis Allen’s Only Yesterday: An Informal History of the 1920s, which Allen—a blueblood journalist and editor at Harper’s—published in 1931. The book chronicles all of the movement and motion that makes the decade sexy, and doesn’t seem to miss a fad.
blogDetail.text8: Allen is also really good at describing parties—or, at least, the ones the middle class and upper class attended. The historian wrote about how women taking up smoking had “strewed the dinner table with their ashes, snatched a puff between the acts, invaded the masculine sanctity of the club car.
blogDetail.quote: A designer knows he has achieved perfection not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away.

projectDetails.title: Project Details
projectDetails.description2: 'The most dreadful part of all,' the old stag answered, 'is that the dogs believe what the hound just said. They believe it, they pass their lives in fear, they hate Him and themselves and yet they'd die for His sake.' There's not a word in either of our language for what you are to me

hero.subtitle: 預約及排隊系統
hero.title: 以智能預約系統提升診所營運效率
hero.description: 專為診所設計，支援診斷、治療、藥房及付款的自動多隊列流程。簡化營運流程，提升顧客滿意度。

feature1.title: 線上系統
feature1.description: 線上系統有助保持距離及預防疾病傳播。

feature2.title: 診所多隊列支援
feature2.description: 專為診斷、治療、藥房及付款流程設計的自動多隊列流程

feature3.title: 節省員工時間
feature3.description: 自動化預約安排及隊列管理，減少人手工作及行政負擔

feature4.title: 用戶友善介面
feature4.description: 直觀的設計適合顧客及員工使用，確保易於採用及高效營運

feature5.title: 提升顧客滿意度
feature5.description: 減少等候時間，透過有序的隊列管理提供更佳的病人體驗

feature6.title: 24/7 線上預約
feature6.description: 顧客可隨時隨地透過網頁或流動裝置介面預約

feature7.title: 自動提醒
feature7.description: 透過短訊、WhatsApp 及電郵自動發送預約提醒，減少缺席率

feature8.title: 排隊系統整合
feature8.description: 完全整合我們專業的排隊系統，實現無縫的病人流程管理

howItWorks.title: 簡單高效的流程
howItWorks.subtitle: 運作方式
howItWorks.note: 立即開始，體驗診所營運的轉變

step1.title: 自動生成時間表
step1.description: 系統根據診所可用時間及員工容量自動生成最佳預約時間表

step2.title: 線上預約
step2.description: 顧客可在方便時透過網頁或流動裝置介面線上預約

step3.title: 員工確認
step3.description: 員工審核並確認預約，按需要作出調整，並為病人到訪作準備

step4.title: 自動提醒
step4.description: 系統透過短訊、WhatsApp 及電郵發送自動提醒，減少缺席並提高出席率

advancedFeatures.title: 進階隊列管理
advancedFeatures.subtitle: 強大功能
advancedFeatures.note: 聯絡我們的團隊，了解更多為您診所度身訂造的進階功能

slider1.title: 組織所有登記
slider1.description: 在集中式控制台管理及組織所有已登記的顧客。實時追蹤病人在診斷、治療、藥房及付款隊列中的狀態。

slider2.title: 自動生成服務次序
slider2.description: 根據登記時間、預約優先次序及診所工作流程自動生成最佳服務次序。確保整個設施內公平高效的病人流程。

slider3.title: 實時狀態更新
slider3.description: 為病人提供實時隊列位置及預計等候時間更新。讓所有人知情並減少候診區的焦慮。

customers.title: 深受領先機構信賴
customers.subtitle: 我們的客戶
customers.description: 我們榮幸為香港各政府部門、醫療機構及服務中心提供服務

review1.name: 黃安雅醫生
review1.title: 診所主任
review1.description: 預約系統徹底改變了我們診所的營運。我們減少了40%的缺席率，員工可以更專注於病人護理而非行政工作。

review2.name: 陳先生
review2.title: 營運經理
review2.description: 與現有排隊管理系統完美整合。透過 WhatsApp 發送的自動提醒在提高預約出席率方面特別有效。

review3.name: 李女士
review3.title: 醫療行政人員
review3.description: 病人和員工都覺得介面易用。診斷、治療、藥房及付款的多隊列流程顯著簡化了我們整個工作流程。

contact.title: 立即開始
contact.subtitle: 聯絡我們
contact.description: 準備好改變您的診所營運了嗎？聯絡我們的團隊進行諮詢，了解我們的預約系統如何為您服務。

info4.title: 地址
info4.text: 香港九龍灣宏開道6號精進工業大廈A座7樓A7室
